column1: Pinworms are small worms that infect the intestines.
Typically, children are infected by touching pinworm eggs without knowing it and then putting their fingers in their mouth.
These eggs can be transferred to other children, family members, and items in the house.

- Difficulty sleeping due to the itching that occurs during the night - Intense itching around the anus - Irritability due to itching and interrupted sleep - Irritated or infected skin around the anus, from constant scratching - Irritation or discomfort of the vagina in young girls (if an adult worm enters the vagina rather than the anus) - Loss of appetite and weight (uncommon, but can occur in severe infections)
The provider will stick the tape to a slide and look for eggs using a microscope.

To control the eggs: - Clean toilet seats daily - Keep fingernails short and clean - Wash all bed linens twice a week - Wash hands before meals and after using the toilet Avoid scratching the infected area around the anus.
Keep your hands and fingers away from your nose and mouth unless they are freshly washed.
Call for an appointment with your health care provider if: - You or your child has symptoms of pinworm infection - You have seen pinworms on your child
